truth: A project is finished when the budget is gone, not when the work is done.
Wally’s law: If you never do any work, you’ll never have to redo it.
The quality of a decision is inversely proportional to the number of people in the meeting.
Status reports are just creative writing for engineers.
The 'Vision' for a project is usually a hallucination from a management retreat.
An expert is anyone from out of town with a PowerPoint deck.
The goal of a reorganization is to hide the failure of the previous one.
Carrying a coffee mug makes you look too busy to be interrupted.
The boss’s technical knowledge is a dangerous mix of buzzwords and overconfidence.
A 'stretch goal' is a task that is physically impossible to achieve.
The person who says 'it’s a win-win' is the only one winning.
Corporate culture is what happens when you ignore the people actually working.
The more you explain it, the more the boss thinks it’s easy.
A 'Strategic Partnership' is two companies failing together.
Efficiency is the art of avoiding tasks that have no purpose.
The amount of 'collaboration' required is directly related to the lack of leadership.
Leadership is the art of taking credit for things that happened by accident.
The 'Next Big Thing' is just the Last Big Thing with a new logo.
If you act like you know what you’re doing, people will leave you alone.
Innovation is just a fancy word for 'trying something that won't work'.
A 'Brainstorming Session' is where good ideas go to die.
The boss’s priority is whatever he read in an airplane magazine this morning.
Work-life balance is a myth told to new hires during orientation.
The complexity of a task expands to fit the number of managers involved.
An 'Urgent Request' is usually a task someone forgot about for three weeks.
The most productive part of the day is the hour after the boss leaves.
Synergy is the sound of two departments bumping heads.
A 'flat hierarchy' means you have twelve bosses instead of one.
Professionalism is the mask you wear to keep from laughing during meetings.
The office coffee is the only thing more bitter than the staff.
A 'Pivot' is a fancy way of saying 'We have no idea what we're doing'.
The best way to be invisible is to volunteer for a committee that never meets.
Training is a way to ensure everyone makes the same mistakes.
Mentorship is just a senior person telling you how things used to be better.
The budget is a list of things you can’t have.
A 'Team Building Exercise' is a way to make everyone hate each other equally.
The boss’s door is always open, but his mind is always closed.
A 'Mission Statement' is a paragraph that means nothing to everyone.
Promotion is the reward for being the best at pretending to work.
Performance reviews are based on how much the boss remembers from last week.
If you don't know what you're doing, do it with 'Agile' enthusiasm.
The 'Cloud' is just a way to pay for someone else’s mistakes monthly.
Scalability is a problem you'll never have for a product nobody wants.
User feedback is a polite way of being told your design is terrible.
A 'Minor Tweak' usually involves rewriting the entire backend.
The office printer can smell fear and will jam accordingly.
A deadline is a date that exists solely to be moved.
Best practices are the things everyone talks about but nobody does.
An 'Open Office' is a way to ensure no one gets any work done together.
The ultimate goal of any corporation is to replace people with spreadsheets.
An 'On-Call' rotation is just a way to ensure employees never truly stop working.
HR defines 'Senior Engineer' as anyone who hasn't quit in the last six months.
Performance metrics are designed to reward those who create problems and then fix them.
A 'Market Adjustment' is what we call a raise that is still below inflation.
Unlimited PTO is a psychological trap to make you feel guilty for taking a Tuesday off.
The 'Greatest Asset' of the company is the one we are currently trying to outsource.
Employee engagement surveys are used to identify who still has hope, so we can fix that.
A 'Competitive Salary' means we pay exactly one dollar more than the worst company in town.
We value your 'Work-Life Balance' as long as the 'Life' part happens between 2 AM and 4 AM.
The 'Standard Tech Stack' is chosen by the person who can be bribed with the cheapest lunch.
Retention bonuses are just ransoms we pay to people we should have treated better.
An 'Exit Interview' is a formal process for ignoring why people are actually leaving.
The 'Culture Fit' interview is a filter for people who won't complain about the broken CI/CD.
We call it 'Upskilling' when we give you three people's jobs for the price of one.
The 'Employee of the Month' is usually the person whose login hasn't been seen in the logs.
Mandatory training is the only time developers are allowed to be idle without being judged.
A 'Horizontal Move' is a way to give you more work without changing your title or pay.
The 'Hiring Freeze' only applies to the roles that would actually make your life easier.
We use 'Agile' because it's easier to track your micro-failures every two weeks.
A 'Bonus' is a theoretical concept used to keep you from leaving before the end of Q4.
The 'Office Perk' of free snacks is a calculated investment to keep you from leaving for lunch.
Remote work is a privilege we threaten to revoke whenever the CEO feels lonely.
The 'Tech Debt' we ignore today is the 'Critical Emergency' we’ll blame you for tomorrow.
Job descriptions are written by people who think 'Java' and 'JavaScript' are siblings.
The 'Open Floor Plan' was invented to make sure no one accidentally enjoys their job.
If your code is easy to maintain, you are making yourself too easy to replace.
The 'Annual Review' is an exercise in finding one minor mistake to justify a 2% raise.
We promote the most incompetent people so they can stop breaking the codebase.
A 'Collaborative Environment' means you are responsible for everyone else's mistakes.
Transparency is a one-way mirror: we see everything you do; you see nothing we decide.
The 'Company Mission' is just a screensaver designed to mask the sound of your despair.
DevOps is the perfect HR strategy: developers now have to fire themselves when the site goes down.
We value 'Creative Problem Solving,' unless your solution involves spending any money.
An 'Inclusive Workspace' means we ignore everyone's technical concerns equally.
The 'Internal Tool' you built will be replaced by a SaaS that does half the work for ten times the cost.
We call it a 'Pivot' when we realize the developers were right six months ago.
The 'Security Audit' is a list of things we’ll fix as soon as we get hacked.
Your 'Passionate Commitment' is just a fancy way of saying you have no hobbies.
The 'Cloud Migration' is a strategic move to ensure we can't blame our own hardware anymore.
A 'Full-Stack Developer' is an HR term for a person who will be burnt out in 18 months.
If you automate your job, you've just provided us with a reason to fire you.
The 'Legacy System' is the only thing standing between the company and total collapse.
We don't have 'Bugs,' we have 'Unscheduled Feature Divergences'.
The 'Technical Roadmap' is a work of fiction that would make Tolkien jealous.
Your 'Autonomy' ends the moment the boss sees a new shiny object.
A 'Reorg' is the corporate version of 'Have you tried turning it off and on again?'
The 'Employee Handbook' is a 400-page document explaining why nothing is our fault.
We encourage 'Feedback' so we can track who the troublemakers are.
The 'Innovation Lab' is where we send the developers we can't trust with production code.
Management is the art of moving the goalposts while the ball is in the air.
You write code faster than you read it.
Most bugs come from assumptions, not syntax.
Meetings often replace actual work.
Deadlines make you cut corners.
Tests are written after the code breaks.
Code reviews find your mistakes, not theirs.
You fix the same bug multiple times.
Documentation is always outdated.
Refactoring feels good but breaks things.
You ignore warnings until they become errors.
Code comments explain the obvious.
You learn more from failures than successes.
Simple solutions are often overlooked.
Time estimates are always wrong.
You write code you don't understand.
The person who talks the most about productivity is avoiding work.
The urgent task is rarely the important one.
Most decisions are made before the meeting starts.
The plan only works until reality shows up.
Someone will always suggest rewriting everything.
The clearer your explanation, the less people listen.
The person who assigns the task will never do it.
The bigger the launch, the smaller the testing window.
You will debug something you didn't change.
Most problems are discovered by users, not systems.
The process exists because something broke once.
The fastest way to delay work is to optimize it.
Someone will ask for changes after approval.
The simplest explanation is usually ignored first.
Every shortcut adds a future meeting.
The person who wants it fastest will review it slowest.
Work expands to fill the deadline.
The issue you can't explain is the one you caused.
The longer the thread, the less anyone reads it.
The system behaves exactly as it was built, not as intended.
If everyone agrees immediately, someone misunderstood.
The more slides there are, the less clarity there is.
Most urgency is manufactured.
You will fix something that was not broken.
The person most confident is usually guessing.
The real bottleneck is usually approval.
The feature request describes a symptom, not the problem.
The more stakeholders, the slower the truth.
Someone will propose a solution before hearing the problem.
You will understand the issue right after explaining it.
Every tool promises simplicity and delivers configuration.
The system that cannot fail is already failing quietly.
Someone will ask for metrics no one plans to read.
The explanation that makes sense is the one people doubt.
The more approvals required, the less ownership exists.
The problem marked minor becomes critical.
Someone will test it in a way you never imagined.
The system is only stable because nobody touched it.
The person who wrote it is no longer here.
Every roadmap is optimistic fiction.
The more planning there is, the less clarity remains.
The real issue is always discovered last.
You will fix it after someone watches you fail.
The person who said it was easy has never done it.
The task that looks small hides the most dependencies.
The more documentation exists, the less it is trusted.
The fastest solution creates the slowest maintenance.
Someone will blame the system before reading it.
The last change is always suspected first.
You will eventually understand code you once feared.
It worked on my machine is the first stage of grief.
DevOps is just developers doing the stuff they used to hate.
A temporary fix is the most permanent thing in the codebase.
The CI pipeline only fails when you are about to leave for dinner.
YAML is just a very sensitive way to yell at a cloud.
DNS is always the prime suspect, even when it isn't.
There is no 'Cloud,' just someone else's computer on fire.
Automating a mess just makes the mess happen faster.
Senior developers are just junior developers who have broken more things.
The 'Force Push' is the 'I give up' of version control.
Microservices turn your code problems into networking problems.
A 'Quick Sync' is never quick.
Deleting code is more satisfying than writing it.
Legacy code is just code that actually makes the company money.
The environment you didn't test is the one where the bug lives.
Dark mode is the only true way to write code.
Naming things is 90% of the difficulty of engineering.
Regex is a way to solve one problem by creating two more.
The louder the server fan, the closer you are to a promotion.
Kubernetes is Greek for 'I have too much free time'.
A deployment at 4:55 PM on a Friday is a cry for help.
Containers only solve the problem of it working on your machine.
Serverless just means the server is someone else's problem.
The 'Dev' in DevOps finishes in a week; the 'Ops' takes a lifetime.
Your 'Quick Fix' is the root cause of next month's outage.
Automated tests are great until you have to maintain the tests.
Technical debt is like a credit card: eventually, you hit the limit.
The person who broke the build is usually the one who left for lunch.
Microservices are just a way to have 50 small outages instead of one big one.
The README is the first thing people ignore and the last thing they update.
Everything is a 'High Priority' until the developer asks for a specification.
The bug you can't reproduce in Staging is currently destroying Production.
Logging everything is the same as logging nothing.
Software estimation is just professional guessing under pressure.
Cloud costs only go one way: up.
A junior dev writes complex code; a senior dev writes simple code.
Git rebase is for people who want to lie about how messy their work was.
The most dangerous command is 'sudo' followed by 'I think this might work'.
Monitoring tells you it's broken; Observability tells you why you're crying.
The staging environment is just a more expensive version of 'not production'.
If you don't have a test environment, you have a production environment where you test.
The best way to get an answer on Slack is to post the wrong solution.
Scalability is what you worry about when you should be worrying about usability.
Agile is just doing the wrong thing in two-week intervals.
A database is a place where data goes to be forgotten.
The person who says 'it’s just a configuration change' is about to cause an outage.
Legacy systems are the only ones that actually work.
A firewall is a device that blocks the traffic you actually need.
Cache invalidation is the second hardest problem; naming things is still first.
Coffee is the fuel that converts tickets into technical debt.
